#Text=Mr.
#Text=Guerber (Switzerland): I have the honour to\r
#Text=speak on behalf of the Human Security Network,\r
#Text=namely, Austria, Chile, Costa Rica, Greece, Ireland,\r
#Text=Jordan, Mali, Norway, Panama, Slovenia, Thailand,\r
#Text=South Africa as an observer, and my own country,\r
#Text=Switzerland.
#Text=We would like to thank the Togolese presidency\r
#Text=for having convened this important open debate on\r
#Text=women, peace and security, an issue that is at the core\r
#Text=of the Human Security Network.
#Text=Let us further thank the Secretary-General for his\r
#Text=report and his Special Representative on Sexual\r
#Text=Violence in Conflict, Ms.
#Text=Margot Wallstrom, for her\r
#Text=outstanding work and commitment to this sensitive and\r
#Text=complex issue.
#Text=The Human Security Network shares\r
#Text=the views expressed by the Secretary-General in his\r
#Text=recommendations to the Security Council, Member\r
#Text=States, donors and regional organizations.\r
#Text=\r
#Text=Since the adoption of Security Council resolution\r
#Text=1325 (2000), we have witnessed significant advances\r
#Text=in this field, including resolutions 1820 (2008), 1888\r
#Text=(2009) and 1960 (2010), the creation of the post of the\r
#Text=Special Representative on Sexual Violence in Conflict,\r
#Text=as well as the Team of Experts on the Rule of Law and\r
#Text=Sexual Violence in Conflict, which contribute\r
#Text=significantly to strengthening the cooperation between\r
#Text=the United Nations system and Member States in order\r
#Text=to prevent crimes against women and girls.
#Text=In addition,\r
#Text=they help to improve the efficiency of the national\r
#Text=judicial systems in ensuring the rule of law and\r
#Text=bringing perpetrators to justice, including to the\r
#Text=International Criminal Court.
#Text=However, it is deeply disturbing that today we\r
#Text=continue to witness rapes of women, girls and children\r
#Text=in general, in countries in armed conflict but also in\r
#Text=other situations, including post-conflict situations.
#Text=We\r
#Text=recognize the efforts made by some Governments to\r
#Text=put an end to these crimes, to strengthen judicial\r
#Text=systems and to bring those responsible to justice.
#Text=However, as the Secretary-General's report (S/2012/33)\r
#Text=shows, progress remains slow, and in practice the\r
#Text=perpetrators of crimes against women and girls often\r
#Text=go unpunished.
#Text=The Human Security Network therefore urges\r
#Text=Member States to increase their efforts to prevent\r
#Text=conflict-related sexual violence by undertaking all\r
#Text=necessary efforts to implement all applicable legal\r
#Text=provisions in the matter.
#Text=The primary responsibility is\r
#Text=theirs.
#Text=But, at the same time, this constitutes a\r
#Text=challenge for the international community as a whole,\r
#Text=especially for regional and subregional organizations.
#Text=Their role in supporting the efforts of those countries is\r
#Text=crucial.
#Text=The message must be clear; there shall be no\r
#Text=impunity for the perpetrators of such crimes, and the\r
#Text=countries affected and the international community will\r
#Text=not rest until there is accountability and justice is done.
#Text=The provision of genuine support, protection and\r
#Text=the relevant services to the victims and their families is\r
#Text=equally as important as rendering justice.
#Text=In that\r
#Text=context, the support given at the community level is\r
#Text=vital.
#Text=Projects that directly assist victims and their\r
#Text=families to help them overcome the trauma inflicted\r
#Text=upon them are of particularly great value.
#Text=One of the key issues in a post-conflict country is\r
#Text=security sector reform.
#Text=Security is not a "men's issue";\r
#Text=it is a gender issue, and women must be involved in all\r
#Text=\r
#Text=relevant discussions and negotiations from their\r
#Text=inception, and they must also be part of the higher\r
#Text=military ranks, which is where security-related issues\r
#Text=are usually discussed.
#Text=The gender perspective must be\r
#Text=part of the reform and training of all security forces.
#Text=The Human Security Network emphasizes the\r
#Text=importance of the full and equal participation of\r
#Text=women in political processes, including in\r
#Text=peacemaking and peacebuilding.
#Text=Their involvement\r
#Text=ensures the success of those processes.
#Text=At the same\r
#Text=time, conflict-related sexual violence and the specific\r
#Text=needs of women and girls have to be addressed\r
#Text=adequately, both in ceasefire agreements and in peace\r
#Text=agreements.
#Text=Preventing crimes is as crucial as delivering\r
#Text=justice and supporting the victims.
#Text=To that end, we\r
#Text=have to be able to improve the early warning systems\r
#Text=and monitoring mechanisms already in place and to\r
#Text=build upon them where needed.
#Text=They must be capable\r
#Text=of detecting signs of possible crimes and must mobilize\r
#Text=the political and judicial authorities in order to prevent\r
#Text=them.
#Text=They must involve all relevant levels, from the\r
#Text=community level to the provincial and national levels.
#Text=Regional organizations can also play an important role\r
#Text=in the creation of an efficient early warning system.
#Text=Finally, we appreciate the information provided\r
#Text=on the progress made in implementing the monitoring,\r
#Text=analysis and reporting arrangements.
#Text=The collection of\r
#Text=timely, accurate, reliable and objective information on\r
#Text=conflict-related sexual violence is crucial to tailoring\r
#Text=the Council's responses, as well as to enhancing action\r
#Text=to prevent sexual violence.
#Text=We also wish to encourage\r
#Text=the deployment of women protection advisers to United\r
#Text=Nations peacekeeping and special political missions in\r
#Text=order to strengthen the response of the relevant mission\r
#Text=components to conflict-related sexual violence.
#Text=We strongly hope that the Council will be able to\r
#Text=reach an agreement on the presidential statement later\r
#Text=today.
#Text=(spoke in French)\r
#Text=\r
#Text=I will now make a statement in my national\r
#Text=capacity.
#Text=A more detailed version of my statement can\r
#Text=be found in the distributed text.
#Text=Resolutions 1888 (2009) and 1960 (2010) on\r
#Text=women and peace and security constitute a robust\r
#Text=machinery, which demonstrates that the Security\r
#Text=Council and United Nations members are firmly\r
#Text=\r
#Text=resolved to move from advocacy to the effective\r
#Text=implementation of their commitment to combat\r
#Text=conflict-related sexual violence.
#Text=The establishment of\r
#Text=new mandates always raises the crucial issue of\r
#Text=coordination and the efficient use of existing\r
#Text=structures.
#Text=We welcome the fact that it is intended to\r
#Text=preserve the full flexibility of the monitoring, analysis\r
#Text=and reporting arrangements in order to adapt them to\r
#Text=the country-specific needs and circumstances.
#Text=In that\r
#Text=regard, we would like to underscore the importance of\r
#Text=the continued and transparent communication of the\r
#Text=Office of the Special Representative with United\r
#Text=Nations country teams so as to foster ownership and\r
#Text=results-oriented implementation of the new structures\r
#Text=and processes in the field.
#Text=We note with great satisfaction that several\r
#Text=activities have been launched with UN-Women.
#Text=We\r
#Text=hope that such productive cooperation will continue.
#Text=Switzerland recently contributed 3 million Swiss francs\r
#Text=to the United Nations Trust Fund to End Violence\r
#Text=against Women, which is administered by UN-Women.
#Text=The Secretary-General's report on conflict-related\r
#Text=sexual violence contains useful recommendations to\r
#Text=the Security Council, Member States and regional\r
#Text=organizations.
#Text=I would like to recall three of those, in\r
#Text=particular.
#Text=First, prevention is a priority as it is an essential\r
#Text=part of our efforts to protect, in which many\r
#Text=stakeholders have a role to play.
#Text=Specific and time-\r
#Text=bound commitments to put an end to all acts of sexual\r
#Text=violence and to bring their perpetrators to justice can\r
#Text=help to break the cycle of violence.
#Text=We strongly support more systematic measures to\r
#Text=enhance protection against sexual violence and\r
#Text=prevention of its recurrence through transitional justice\r
#Text=mechanisms.
#Text=Such measures should link the fight\r
#Text=against impunity and recognition of victims' rights, for\r
#Text=example through appropriate reparations, but also\r
#Text=include strengthening the national capacity to combat\r
#Text=the causes of violence and, at the same time, to prevent\r
#Text=new cases.
#Text=Secondly, in resolution 1820 (2008), the Security\r
#Text=Council resolved to take acts of sexual violence into\r
#Text=consideration when establishing or renewing State-\r
#Text=specific sanctions regimes.
#Text=That opportunity should not\r
#Text=be forgotten.
#Text=It thus provides the means to take\r
#Text=targeted measures against, for example, the parties and\r
#Text=individuals mentioned in the Secretary-General's report\r
#Text=on sexual violence in conflict.
#Text=Finally, in his report, the Secretary-General calls\r
#Text=on the parties to include training on conflict-related\r
#Text=sexual violence in training programmes for\r
#Text=peacekeeping troops.
#Text=In that regard, I would like to\r
#Text=draw the Council's attention to the handbook prepared\r
#Text=by the Department of Peacekeeping Operations,\r
#Text=entitled "Standardized Best Practices Toolkit on\r
#Text=Gender and Policing in Peacekeeping Operations".
#Text=The\r
#Text=handbook was co-financed by Switzerland.
#Text=The structures set up by resolutions 1888 (2009),\r
#Text=1889 (2009) and 1960 (2010) are still in a testing\r
#Text=phase, and only proof of the reality will make it\r
#Text=possible to assess their effectiveness.
#Text=The path is steep\r
#Text=and rocky.
#Text=However, we should move forward\r
#Text=prudently and resolutely in strengthening the protection\r
#Text=architecture.
#Text=The establishment of the mandate of the\r
#Text=Special Representative of the Secretary-General on\r
#Text=Sexual Violence in Conflict is a significant part of that\r
#Text=course.
